title: Electrochemically Modulated Mineralization of CO2 In OceanWater
LLM Summary: Based on the title, this technology likely can Capture CO2 from ocean water and convert it into solid minerals for storage and removal..\\n\\nIf you would like to learn more about the specific capabilities, technical details, and potential applications of this technology, please reach out to us.
LLM Teaser: The work involves the use of electrochemical methods to influence the process of mineralizing carbon dioxide in ocean water.

title: Multi-Link Modular Continuum Robotic EndoscopeSystem
description: Robotic endoscopes have the potential to help endoscopists position tools during procedures, to propel the endoscope to the desired position, to automate functions and to prevent perforations during procedures. Modular architecture for a continuum robotic endoscope with multiple bending segments along the length of the endoscope. Each of the segments is modular, containing a set of actuation motors that drive short cables in the continuum segments.
Description: Robotic endoscopes have the potential to help endoscopists position tools during procedures, to propel the endoscope to the desired position, to automate functions and to prevent perforations during procedures. Modular architecture for a continuum robotic endoscope with multiple bending segments along the length of the endoscope. Each of the segments is modular, containing a set of actuation motors that drive short cables in the continuum segments.
LLM Summary: **Summary:**  \\nThe Multi-Link Modular Continuum Robotic Endoscope System features a modular architecture that allows for multiple bending segments along its length. Each segment contains actuation motors that control short cables, enabling the endoscope to maneuver effectively while performing procedures.\\n\\n**Applications:**  \\nThis robotic endoscope can be used in medical procedures that require precise tool positioning, such as minimally invasive surgeries or diagnostics. Its automation capabilities may enhance the overall efficiency of endoscopic procedures, potentially improving patient outcomes.\\n\\n**Problem Solved:**  \\nThe system addresses challenges associated with traditional endoscopes, such as positioning tools accurately, navigating complex anatomical features, and minimizing the risk of perforations during procedures. By utilizing a continuum robotic design, it aims to increase the dexterity and control of endoscopic interventions.
LLM Teaser: Robotic endoscopes can assist endoscopists by improving tool positioning, facilitating movement, automating functions, and reducing the risk of perforations during procedures. The proposed design features a modular architecture with multiple bending segments, each equipped with actuation motors and short cables for enhanced maneuverability.

title: Green Propellant Conditioning and Injection System for Bi-Modal Chemical-Electric SpacePropulsion
description: Bi-modal propulsion systems and related methods are generally described. In some embodiments, a bi-modal propulsion system may employ a single propellant for both chemical thruster(s), operating at elevated pressures, and electrical thruster(s) (e.g., electro spray thruster), operating at reduced pressures. The propellant pressure may be reduced to a desired operational range of the electrical thrusters) using any appropriate construction including, for example, capillaries configured to reduce the pressure of the propellant to an operational range of the electrical thrusters). In some embodiments, the reduced pressure of the propellant may be lower than a vapor pressure of at least one volatile component of the propellant, leading to the formation of "bubbles" within the propellant line. The presence of alternating gas and liquid phases along a flow path between a propellant tank and the electrical thruster(s) may help to electrically insulate the electrical thruster from the rest of the system.
Description: Bi-modal propulsion systems and related methods are generally described. In some embodiments, a bi-modal propulsion system may employ a single propellant for both chemical thruster(s), operating at elevated pressures, and electrical thruster(s) (e.g., electro spray thruster), operating at reduced pressures. The propellant pressure may be reduced to a desired operational range of the electrical thrusters) using any appropriate construction including, for example, capillaries configured to reduce the pressure of the propellant to an operational range of the electrical thrusters). In some embodiments, the reduced pressure of the propellant may be lower than a vapor pressure of at least one volatile component of the propellant, leading to the formation of "bubbles" within the propellant line. The presence of alternating gas and liquid phases along a flow path between a propellant tank and the electrical thruster(s) may help to electrically insulate the electrical thruster from the rest of the system.
LLM Summary: **Summary:**\\n\\nThe technology described involves a bi-modal propulsion system that utilizes a single propellant for both chemical and electrical thrusters. The system operates at different pressure levels; chemical thrusters function at elevated pressures, while electrical thrusters, such as electro spray thrusters, operate at reduced pressures. The propellant's pressure can be adjusted to fit the operational range required for the electrical thrusters through various constructions, like capillaries. Notably, the reduced pressure may lead to the formation of gas bubbles within the liquid propellant, creating alternating phases that facilitate electrical insulation between the thruster and the rest of the system.\\n\\n**Applications:**\\n\\nThe bi-modal propulsion system can be applied in space exploration missions where efficient propulsion methods are needed. This includes satellite maneuvers, interplanetary travel, and other aerospace activities that benefit from enhanced propulsion capabilities combining chemical and electrical techniques.\\n\\n**Problem Solved:**\\n\\nThis technology addresses the challenge of using a single propellant effectively for both chemical and electrical thrust generation, thereby simplifying the propulsion system design. It also mitigates risks associated with electrical insulation in thruster systems, enhancing operational safety and performance by managing pressure variations within the propellant flow.
LLM Teaser: Bi-modal propulsion systems utilize a single propellant for both chemical thrusters, which operate at elevated pressures, and electrical thrusters, such as electro spray thrusters, which function at reduced pressures. The system is designed to reduce the propellant pressure to the desired operational range for the electrical thrusters using appropriate construction methods, including capillaries.
